article_title: Health plans’ narrow networks a struggle for consumers
article_text:
Health plans’ narrow networks a struggle for consumers

Photo: Express-News File Photo Isabel Montalvo (left) and her husband, Eraldo Montalvo, examined...

When his Blue Cross Blue Shield of Texas PPO health insurance plan was discontinued, Ken Davis of La Vernia soldiered on and tried to make the best of it.

article_metadata.description: For 2016, he purchased another Blue Cross plan through the federal exchange for himself and his wife — a less flexible HMO requiring the couple to stick to a provider network and seek referrals from their primary care physician before seeing specialists.  Since PPOs were severely curtailed or eliminated from the federal exchange in Texas effective Jan. 1, some consumers and insurance brokers have faced challenges trying to navigate the new landscape.  Many consumers now are adjusting to less popular types of health coverage, such as health maintenance organization plans and exclusive provider organization plans, which limit care to a defined network of doctors and hospitals.  Humana said its networks ensure access to high-quality care and preserve the company’s ability to offer affordable products to the public.  Texas customers who hoped to renew their PPOs in 2016 were in disbelief when they learned that option had been eliminated, said Justin Holland, the owner of locally based Texas State Financial & Health and a member of the San Antonio Association of Health Underwriters.  “Premiums increased, deductibles increased, out-of-pocket maxes increased and almost every single individual health insurance client was affected from the loss of their PPO or the fact that doctors will not accept ACA-compliant EPOs or HMOs,” Holland said of his customers in an email.  During a recent stop in San Antonio, federal Health and Human Services Secretary Sylvia Burwell said the changes in the Texas market are happening partly because insurers have seen a “reduction in demand” for PPO health plans.  Health and Human Services officials said the reduction in PPOs started before the Affordable Care Act took effect as insurance companies took steps to better control their costs.  Consumers increasingly have opted for HMOs and other health insurance alternatives over PPOs in the private market, the department insisted.  If every health care provider is included in an insurance plan’s network, “then the insurance company has very little bargaining power to get good rates,” he said.
article_metadata.author.name: By Peggy O'Hare, Staff Writer
